importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's update, indicating the most current reporting on NFL Week 7 results and developments.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season, which spans late September to early October, highlighting key matchups and performance trends in the season's early phase.

keyTakeAways: The NFL season has seen an unprecedented number of late-game comebacks, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation through Week 7 — the most in NFL history over that span.

The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter to defeat the New York Giants 33-32, becoming the first team since 2007 to overcome a shutout and 18-point lead after three quarters.

Second-year quarterback Bo Nix delivered a breakout performance, throwing for 174 yards and two touchdowns and rushing for two scores, ultimately leading the Broncos to victory with a final field goal as time expired.

Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of his passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards in a single game.

The Miami Dolphins and New York Jets both suffered significant losses, with Miami's Tua Tagovailoa throwing three interceptions (including one returned for a TD) and being benched in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers, and Jets' Justin Fields benched at halftime due to poor first-half performance, replaced by Tyrod Taylor.
The Jets' first-year head coach Aaron Glenn confirmed a quarterback change, signaling instability in the team's offensive leadership amid a 0-7 start.
The Green Bay Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals 27-23 with a final-quarter touchdown and a key defensive stop by Micah Parsons, who recorded his third sack of the game on Arizona’s final drive.

The article highlights a broader trend of unpredictability and high-stakes comebacks in the NFL, emphasizing the volatility of early-season performance and the impact of quarterback performance on team outcomes.

namedEntities.name: Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Denver Broncos are central to the story of a historic comeback, marking the first team in NFL history to overcome a 19-point deficit after being shut out and leading by 18 points after three quarters.

namedEntities.name: New York Giants
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The New York Giants were the opposing team in the Denver Broncos' dramatic comeback, highlighting how a team that had a strong start can be overturned by late-game momentum.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bo Nix played a pivotal role in the Broncos' comeback, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, and ultimately leading a last-minute victory with a game-winning field goal.

namedEntities.name: Marvin Mims
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Marvin Mims was targeted in the final moments of the game, receiving a critical pass that set up the game-winning field goal for the Broncos.

namedEntities.name: Courtland Sutton
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Courtland Sutton was a key target in the final drive, helping set up the game-winning field goal with deep passes from Bo Nix.

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Packers made a late comeback against the Arizona Cardinals, scoring two touchdowns in the final quarter and forcing a turnover on downs, showcasing resilience and defensive strength.

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brissett led the Arizona Cardinals in a desperate final drive, but was disrupted by the Packers’ defense, including Micah Parsons, who ended the game with a crucial sack.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Micah Parsons, traded from the Dallas Cowboys to Green Bay, recorded a key sack on the Cardinals’ final drive and was disruptive throughout the game, contributing to the Packers’ victory.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Drake Maye made history with a 91.3% completion rate, surpassing Tom Brady’s franchise record of 88.5%, and becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards in one game.

namedEntities.name: Tom Brady
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tom Brady’s franchise record of 88.5% completion rate is referenced as a benchmark that Drake Maye broke, marking a significant shift in the evolution of quarterback performance standards.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots are highlighted as a team undergoing a quarterback transition, with Drake Maye emerging as a potential long-term leader after a strong performance in Week 7.

namedEntities.name: Tennessee Titans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Titans were defeated by the Patriots in a game where Drake Maye delivered a historic performance, showing the impact of a new quarterback on team success.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tagovailoa had a disastrous performance in the Miami Dolphins’ loss to the Browns, throwing three interceptions, including one returned for a touchdown, leading to his benching.

namedEntities.name: Quinn Ewers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ewers was promoted to start in the fourth quarter after Tagovailoa’s poor performance, signaling a shift in the Dolphins' offensive strategy and leadership.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fields struggled in the first half of the Jets’ loss to the Panthers, leading to his benching at halftime, and was replaced by Tyrod Taylor.

namedEntities.name: Tyrod Taylor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor replaced Fields in the second half and was more effective, though he still threw two costly interceptions, indicating ongoing instability in the Jets' offense.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Glenn
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Glenn, the first-year head coach of the Jets, made the decision to bench Justin Fields at halftime, highlighting team instability and the challenges of building a winning culture.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vrabel, who was fired by the Titans in January 2024, now has a victory in his first game against the Patriots, showing a potential turnaround in coaching success and team dynamics.

namedEntities.name: Cleveland Browns
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Browns defeated the Miami Dolphins 31-6, contributing to the Dolphins' poor start and leading to the benching of Tua Tagovailoa.

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Chargers

namedEntities.name: Dallas Cowboys

namedEntities.name: San Francisco 49ers

namedEntities.name: Jacksonville Jaguars

namedEntities.name: New Orleans Saints

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was marked by dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and significant coaching changes. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit against the New York Giants, with second-year quarterback Bo Nix delivering a career-defining performance that included a final game-winning field goal. Meanwhile, Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a dominant 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era history to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush over 50 yards in a single game. On the flip side, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets both suffered major losses, with Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields being benched due to poor performances, respectively. The Jets' first-year coach Aaron Glenn admitted the team needed a spark, while the Dolphins’ coaching staff turned to rookie Quinn Ewers. The week underscored the NFL’s volatility, with teams showing both resilience and fragility, and highlighted a broader theme of late-game comebacks being more frequent than ever in NFL history.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
